ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learn about different SDGs and how to run a project that can bring an impact to our community.
I learned all about the sustainable development goals as well as how to lead my own project and develop it
This course was helpful in encouraging us to think about practical solutions to real problems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had different speakers from organizations such as the UN, World Bank, CT Greek Bank, etc who come to every class and share insights on their roles. It is a great opportunity not only to learn more about ongoing efforts in addressing climate change but also ask them career-related questions.

Only strengths. I absolutely LOVED this course. By far my favourite during my time at Yale. It has been incredible and I definitely recommend it for all EVST and non-EVST majors alike! It is incredibly engaging and you can lead your own project in whatever direction you like.

Strengths of this class included a wide variety of interesting speakers, very helpful and involved TAs, and mostly clear expectations & speedy feedback on work submitted.

No major weaknesses to speak of. This was a great class! One small thing was that it was a little challenging to approach the main project of the class- it was a great project and I learned a lot ultimately, but starting it was confusing and a little overwhelming. I felt as though I had much less of a basis in what this type of class asked for compared to other students. Many of these other students were graduate students as well, which was a little bit intimidating. Probably 90% a me thing and not a "this class" thing, but it might be helpful to explicitly set up appts with undergraduates or directly address them in the first class to ensure that we are on the right page regarding the asks of the central project.
Having such a variety of speakers was incredibly useful. Additionally, developing tangible solutions to problems as the primary assignment was invaluable to me.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The speaker format served these circumstances well. Asking questions to the speakers was easy and straightforward, but getting conversation going between other students was challenging. I think it's hard to avoid this over Zoom, definitely not a failing of the class.
I believe this lecture/discussion was incredibly well-done and accommodating.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a fantastic course and, if you can, TAKE IT!! If you're not an EVST major, no worries, because this course lets you take your project in whatever direction you choose, so you can focus it more on biology/physical science, econ/finance/consulting, international relations, anthropology...whatever you want!

I would absolutely recommend this class to other students, and have already actually. It was a great experience and I learned a lot about different sustainability-minded projects happening around the world. The opportunity to listen to so many speakers, both local and international, was an opportunity I'm really glad to have had. The professor was also very aware of the challenges that students were facing due to local events and COVID, and the TA was always available, enthusiastic, encouraging, and helpful. I felt valued as a student in this class, and challenged in a positive way.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lecture, at times more a seminar format
Each lecture was live, but also recorded.
